child.pub-comments: Loukotka (1968:273-4) lists most of these as separate languages in his “Mapuche stock” (with one addition, Chilote): Mapuche [Araucano], Picunche, Moluche [Nguluche], Huiliche [Veliche], Chilote [Chauquéz].

child.pub-comments: Culle is sometimes thought be related to Cholonan (see for example Kaufman 2007:69), but is so poorly documented a determination of its genetic affinity is difficult; the primary sources on the language are two word lists, one of 19 words, the other of 43 (Adelaar 2004:401-3).
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Local varieties: Apatama, Casabindo, Churumata, Cochinoca
Campbell calls this a local variety.

child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Sometimes wrongly classified with Huitotoan. Andoque shares some typological similarities with Arawakan, Tukanoan, and Huitotoan), but the evidence does not permit classifying it with any other language family (Landaburu 2000:30).
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Only four words are known, Loukotka 1968:89.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Taushiro was missed by most classifiers except Tovar (1961, though not repeated in Tovar and Tovar 1984), who grouped it with Omurano. Kaufman (1994:63) notes certain lexical resemblances “that tend to support Tovar’s claim.” “Pinche” is grouped with Candoshi by Loukotka (1968) and Tovar and Tovar (1984), but Taushiro is considered Zaparoan in Kaufman (1994:63). Kaufman (1994:63) also reports Taushiro lexical similarities with Candoshi and with Omurano.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: A proposed grouping of Ticuna with Arawakan did not survive scrutiny. Kaufman (2007:68) proposes to place it with Yurí and Munichi in his “Juri-Tikuna Stock.”
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Kaufman (1994:70) reports that “not even Gr[eenberg] dares classify this language".
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.
Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.
Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Rivet (1943) proposed several relatives of Candoshi among now extinct languages of northern Peru, most unconvincing. Chirino has only four words recorded, but they seem sufficient to favor the Candoshi connection (Adelaar 2004:406, Torero 2002:280-3). Loukotka (1968:156) also had several others, including Chirino, in his “Murato stock”: Shapra (Iñuru, Zapa), Pinche (Llepa, Uchpa, Avaza [see Taushiro, below, now considered an independent isolate]), Sacata, and Rabona.
child.alt-names: Candoxi, Maina, Kandoshi, Shapra, Murato, Roamaina

child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Betoi consists of several dialects or related languages: Airico, Betoi, Ele, Jirara, Lolaca, Situfa (Adelaar 2004:161); their status is not certain. Possibly a small family.

child.pub-comments: Loukotka (1968:163) lists in his “Huari stock” several of these alternative names as separate languages, including also: Aboba, Maba, Puxacáze, and Guajejú as additional languages but of which “nothing” was known.
child.alt-names: Aikanã, Huarí, Warí, Masaká, Kasupá, Mundé, Corumbiara, Tubarão

child.pub-comments: The proposed Chibchan connection of Andaquí has been discounted; it is sometimes associated with Paezan, though with no compelling evidence.

child.pub-comments: Ethnologue mentions it is "possibly related to Kirirí [Karirí]".
child.alt-names: Pancararu, Pancarurú, Brancararú, Pankarará, Pankarú, Pancaru, Pancaré, Pankaravu, Pankaroru
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: The Ethnologue (though no one else) list this as a member of the Arutani-Sape family (of only two members); that is, it links the two isolates Awaké and Kaliana. See Migliazza (1985[1982]:51). Dixon and Aikhenvald (1999:20) list "Sape" among the "few languages that we say nothing about, for the simple reason that almost nothing is know about them." (Migliazza 1978, 1980.)
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Kaufman (1994:70) says of Otí that of the large-scale classifiers “only Greenberg dares to link this language to anything else.” Ethnologue links its Oti to Macro-Jé.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.
Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Ethnologue lists Arutani (Auaqué, Auake, Awaké, Uruak, Urutani, Aoaqui, Oewaku) as a member of their Arutani-Sape classification, a joining of the Awaké and Kaliana isolates. Dixon and Aikhenvald (1999:20) list Awaké among the "few languages that we say nothing about, for the simple reason that almost nothing is know about them." (Migliazza 1978.)
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Chono is extinct, from the northern Kaweskar region, very poorly attested, principally from a catequism without translation. There has been confusion about its classification. Some reportedly Chono materials make it appear to be a variant of Kaweskar (Alacaluf), but the material presented by Bausani (1975) from the eighteenth century catechism shows it to be different from Kaweskar (Adelaar 2004:553), suggesting that it is a distinct language, unrelated to others of the region. Chono is also sometimes equated with Aksanás, another confusing term. Aksanás as identified today is one name for Northern Kaweskar. Loukotka (1968:44) had an Aksanás stock with two languages, Chono (Caucau) and Kaueskar (Aksanás), not connected with his Alacaluf “isolated language” (Loukotka 1968:43). Aksaná(s) is left out of this classification, on the assumption that Clairis (1978:32, 1985:756) is correct in showing that the assumed Aksaná(s) language (not Kaweskar) does not really exist.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: This Máko is an isolate, not to be confused with the Makuan languages.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Usually included in the Macro-Jê hypothesis, though this has recently been questioned.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.
Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Loukotka (1968:259) gave as languages in his “Yurimangui stock”: Yurimangui, Timba, Lili, Yolo (Paripazo), Jamundi, and Puscajae (Pile).
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Adelaar (2004:321) "for the time being, the Mochica language most be considered as a language isolate." It is often linked with extinct Cañar (Cañari) and Puruhá (Puruguay) of Ecuador, but there is virtually no attestation of these languages. (See Cerrón-Palomino 1995.) Kaufman (2009:69), nevertheless, gives a "Chimuan family" made up of: Mochica, Kanyari, and Puruwá. Loukotka’s (1968:26-2) "Chimú stock" included Chimú and the following in his "Northern Languages" branch: Ayahuaca, Calva, Tumbi (Tumbez), Puná (Lapuna), Colonche, Chanduy, Tacame (Atacamez) [now considered Esmeralda, and independent isolate], Chongón, Coaque, Manabi (Manta) Huancavilca, Cañari, and Puruhá (Puruguai).
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Puquina was one of the three languages that was recognized in 1575 as a lengua general in colonial Peru, used for administration and for religion. It had great prestige, but in spite of that soon became extinct. There is an old long-standing misunderstanding according to which Puquina is considered to be closely related with Uru-Chipaya, although they have almost nothing in common. This error comes from the fact that Uru and Chipaya each have often been called “Puquina” (Adelaar 1989:43, 175, 252, Mason 1950:224; Olson 1964:314). This error was pointed out and corrected long ago and repeated frequently (see Chamberlain 1910, Ibarra Grasso 1958:10, 1964:37-3, and for details Campbell 1997:189, 210). In spite of this, the mistaken classification of Puquina with Uru-Chipaya has often been repeated (for example, Crequi-Montfort and Rivet 1925-7, Greenberg 1987:xx; Noble 1965, Tovar 1961:47-9; etc.; see also Mason 1950:224-5). Callahuaya (Machaj-Juyai, Collahuaya, Pohena) is a jargonized (or mixed) language based predominantly on lexical items from Puquina and morphology from Quechua, used by male curers who live in a few villages in the provinces of Muñecas and Bautista Saavedra, Department of La Paz, Bolivia, but who travel widely throughout this part of South America to practice their curing profession. It has generally been considered to be a much changed variety of (or relative of) Puquina.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Martins (2005:341) mentions that the data point to a probable Makúan affinity for Hodï, possibly connected with the Kakwa group of languages, but this is unconfirmed. (See Mattei-Miller et al. 1996.) The Ethnologue mentions possible connections to Yamomanan and Sáliban languages (www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=yau).] Dixon and Aikhenvald (1999:20) list "Hoti" among the "few languages that we say nothing about, for the simple reason that almost nothing is know about them."
child.alt-names: Yoana, Yuana, Yuwana, Waruwaru Waruwádu, Chicano, Chikano, Joti, Jodi, Hotí
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.alt-names: Sibundoy, Coche, Kamsá, Kamemtxa, Kamse, Camëntsëá, Mocoa
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.
Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Dixon and Aikhenvald (1999:20) list Kanoé among the "few languages that we say nothing about, for the simple reason that almost nothing is know about them."

child.pub-comments: Sometimes grouped with Chibchan, but without justification. Kaufman (2007:68) places it with Yaruro and Esmeralda (Tacame) in his "Takame-Jarúroan stock."

child.pub-comments: Loukotka 1968:87 mentioned that there are "only three words" known of this language, but in comparison with other languages (p.88) listed five.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Yurí is poorly known and probably extinct; the evidence does not support earlier attempts to group it with either Arawakan or Cariban. Kaufman (2007:68) places it with Tikuna and Munichi in his “Juri-Tikuna stock.”
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.). 2012. The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: Not to be confused with the Karirian family.

child.pub-comments: Loukotka (1968:158) also included Tiwituey (Tuei) in his Sabela stock.
